bibl.title: Despatch from M. A. Aenmey to Frederick T. Frelinghuysen
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p:
Consulate General of the United States
Monrovia, April 26th 1882
Mr M. A Aenmey to the Secretary of State
Subject
Attack by a mob on the Consular Agency of the United States at Grand Bassa

Consulate General of the U.S.
Monrovia April 26th 1882
Sir
I sincerely regret to be obliged to report that, a few weeks ago, at Grand Bassa, a demonstration took place, against the person of the U.S. Consular Agent, Mr J. W. Worrell.

Imediatly afther receiving, pr extra messenger, the Complaint from the Consular Agent, I imformed the Liberia Governement through the dept of State at Monrovia, of what has took place, requesting must respectfully, to have a proper inquiry made as to the cause of this revolting act.

Afther some delay I have received from the dept of State at answer, herewith enclosed and marked No 2. Since that time Mr Worrell has visited Monrovia and declared to me that no further disturbences has occured, and informed me that the whole act of the unruly crowd that evening was personaly against him and not a demonstration against the Consular Agency and that in fact nothing but politics was the cause. This expression being made to me by
Hon Fredk. T. Frelinghuysen
Secretary of State
Washington D.C.
by Mr Worrell himself, it is my opinion that no further demonstrations of that kind, will take place, as the Governement of Liberia has give order to put an exemplary punishment on the perpetrators of this outrage.

With sentiments of the highest esteem
I am Sir, your obedt servt.
M. A. Aenmey.
Actg Consul General.
Enclosures.

1. Mr J. W. Worrell to Mr. M. A Aenmey
2. Secretary Gibson to Mr M A Aenmey.

U.S. Consulate
Grand Bassa
March 22nd 1882

M. A. Aenmey Esq
U.S. Vice Con: General
Monrovia
Dear Sir

Since writing you on the 16th inst I have to further inform you that this Consulate was attacked by an Armed Mob & fired into on two occasions during the evening of the 18th inst, inflicting a slight wound on myself & seriously injuring his honor the mayor of the City Buchanan, who happened to be in my Company on the verando of this Consulate. The actions of The local Authorities here in defence of this International outrage I am ashamed
to say reflects no honor on the Chief whom he represents. Up to the present, by his actions, he has not thought the Consulate & Archives of the U.S. Government worthy of any consideration from the Government of Liberia, notwithstanding he is aware that the Mob went so far as to batter the U.S. Court-of-arms of this Consulate with Bullets on the evening of the above complained of outrage. I also enclose a copy of a notice he has since put up on the corner of the streets and also a copy of my notice to him of the course I intend to take in bringing the matter before the U.S. Government

I am Dear Sir
Your obt. servt
John W Worrell
U.S. Com Agt

Department of State
Monrovia April 13, 1882.
Sir.

Referring to your despatch of some days ago, calling attention to the outrage committed upon the United States Consulate at Grand Bassa, I have the honor to express the very sincere regret felt by this Government that any such occurrence should have taken place; and to assure you that the proper authorities at that place have been and still are putting forth earnest efforts to detect the parties committing the outrage in order to bring the same to justice

I have the pleasure to inform you however that after the most vigilant inquiry as to the probable cause of the attack, it has been satisfactorily shown that reasons wholly connected with the late political career of Hon. J W Worrell, who occupies the double position of Liberian Senator and United States Consular Agent accounts for it. Notwithstanding the Government will put forth every effort to detect & punish the offenders.

I have the honor to be
Sir,
Your obedient Servant
G. W. Gibson
div1.fw:
Hon M. A. Aenmey
U States Legation
Monrovia
